text:
Lots of great advice here. I work with a lot of content marketing and journalists on career growth and transitions. Getting the resume right can be overwhelming — I built 3 courses here to align resume with LI profile and Content Strategy.

I am always surprised at how many content experts don’t have a personal content strategy to support their professional reputation. I was just approached by a content strategist & digital marketing boutique firm — they want me as a client, but have no content strategy for their leadership team or their own business. They want to handle my LinkedIn presence but have no presence themselves! Cray cray.

<https://www.renovateyourcareer.com/store>

elements.text:
Lots of great advice here. I work with a lot of content marketing and journalists on career growth and transitions. Getting the resume right can be overwhelming — I built 3 courses here to align resume with LI profile and Content Strategy.

I am always surprised at how many content experts don’t have a personal content strategy to support their professional reputation. I was just approached by a content strategist & digital marketing boutique firm — they want me as a client, but have no content strategy for their leadership team or their own business. They want to handle my LinkedIn presence but have no presence themselves! Cray cray.

text: Hi Redante, I've been a hiring manager for more than 30 years and I love it when writers put links to their writing samples inside their resumes. As a marketing executive and consultant, I personally include 4 pages of links from my consulting career in my resume. So not only do I recommend you do that, I do it myself to show what I have accomplished. It's one thing to SAY you have written something, it's far better to SHOW it. Hope that helps!

elements.text: Hi Redante, I've been a hiring manager for more than 30 years and I love it when writers put links to their writing samples inside their resumes. As a marketing executive and consultant, I personally include 4 pages of links from my consulting career in my resume. text: As a hiring manager, I would optimize the first part of your resume, by deleting the little cartoon character and greeting. I'd just put: full name, email address, phone, LinkedIn, and then the little blurb. Make sense?

elements.text: As a hiring manager, I would optimize the first part of your resume, by deleting the little cartoon character and greeting. I'd just put: full name, email address, phone, LinkedIn, and then the little blurb. Make sense?

text: Many thanks for your feedback! It is good to hear the perspective of a hiring manager

elements.text: Many thanks for your feedback! It is good to hear the perspective of a hiring manager

text: I have a question, how do I approach agency? I mean if I cold email them, what should I write, break the ice? any kind  of cold emails you've sent that works for you?

elements.text: I have a question, how do I approach agency? I mean if I cold email them, what should I write, break the ice? any kind  of cold emails you've sent that works for you?

text: I have seen a lot of cold emailing templates, blogs and videos, but they usually talk about approaching brands and business, but the agency already have in house writer, so no pain point basically

elements.text: I have seen a lot of cold emailing templates, blogs and videos, but they usually talk about approaching brands and business, but the agency already have in house writer, so no pain point basically

text: asking a lot of questions around the expectations for the role, what past investments they've made in the area, how long the last person held this role. Also always think it's a red flag if you cant interview with someone else within the team. I also look try and get an understanding if they're trying to have someone do multiple roles as one person or a higher-level role for less based off the job requirements/expectations

text:
Hi <@U03190ABB53>! Thanks so much for sharing your journey and I completely feel you about the sweet spot being the middle. I agree with you on how product marketing is higher-level strategic thinking and I want to be seen more of a 'business partner' because content isn't always seen in that light.

I'm considering the transition, but I am finding that companies I'm talking to are more interested in my content + editorial skills. I think I might also need to highlight the product work I've done a bit more clearly in my resume/LinkedIn.

elements.text: Hi

! Thanks so much for sharing your journey and I completely feel you about the sweet spot being the middle. I agree with you on how product marketing is higher-level strategic thinking and I want to be seen more of a 'business partner' because content isn't always seen in that light.

I'm considering the transition, but I am finding that companies I'm talking to are more interested in my content + editorial skills. I think I might also need to highlight the product work I've done a bit more clearly in my resume/LinkedIn.

text: Hi <@U02333AMCUW>! I was running content at my last company and when I came back from a mat leave, there was a lot of product marketing work to be done because the company was a) launching a new sub-brand and b) launching a subscription product, as opposed to only offering one-off products. So I decided to make the switch and try it out, focusing on launches, positioning, customer research, educational content, and pricing/packaging optimization. I took the PMA Core certification, which was great, and then recently made the switch to another product marketing role (though there's still a lot of content work involved, as there are no content marketers here yet!). Happy to chat through how I made the switch. I still think there's a huge overlap between content + product marketing, especially at earlier-stage companies, so you can do product marketing while still having a big hand in content.

I still think there's a huge overlap between content + product marketing, especially at earlier-stage companies, so you can do product marketing while still having a big hand in content.

text:
<@U02333AMCUW> Yes I think a lot of companies put these disciplines in completely separate buckets. I've been at tech companies where the product marketers had strong technical / buyer / competitive knowledge but were terrible writers, and companies where no one on the huge marketing team knew enough about the product or audience to write value props.

Sooo many companies lose their story translating the strategic to the tactical. Someone with your skills is a HUGE asset because you can connect the dots. If you're considering making the jump, one place to focus might be startups where they don't yet have headcount to support both roles. Bridging the gap there will be super valuable to both the product team and the growth marketers.

elements.text:

text:
Completely agree with <@U03190ABB53>! I'm also in a PLG/self-serve company right now where product + content marketing are more tied because there's no sales team. You might have more luck making the jump in these types of companies.

This article from MKT1 helped me a lot in making sense of product marketing and where my strengths and skills gaps were. :slightly_smiling_face:
<https://mkt1.substack.com/p/weve-been-defining-product-marketing?s=r>

attachments.fallback: We've been defining product marketing wrong
attachments.text: A guide to product marketing for early-stage startups, includes: list of all product marketing responsibilities & a template to do your own audience analysis.
attachments.title: We've been defining product marketing wrong
